intro: Acacia plicata, commonly known as the narrow-leaf wattle, is a shrub or small tree native to Australia. It is characterized by its feathery, bipinnate leaves that are narrow and arranged in a zigzag pattern. The plant produces yellow flowers in globular clusters, which appear in spring and are followed by long, slender pods. Acacia plicata is drought-tolerant and thrives in well-drained soils, making it adaptable to various arid and semi-arid environments. It is also valued for its ornamental appeal and ability to provide habitat for native wildlife.

This plant typically grows in dry, sandy soils and is often associated with coastal and inland areas. It is well adapted to the arid and semi-arid climates of its native range. Acacia plicata plays an important ecological role in the local vegetation of Western Australia.
